title: Role of the Pretraining and the Adaptation data sizes for low-resource real-time MRI video segmentation
author: Masoud Thajudeen Tholan (Indian Institute of Science), Vinayaka Hegde (Indian Institute of Science), Chetan Sharma (Indian Institute of Science), Prasanta Kumar Ghosh (Indian Institute of Science)
relevance_why: The methodologies presented for effective model adaptation in low-resource settings could inform approaches in audio-related tasks, especially for segmenting or reconstructing audio signals in various conditions.
background: This research investigates the segmentation of tissue boundaries in real-time Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) videos, focusing on the impact of pretraining and adaptation data size on model accuracy.
contribution: This paper introduces strategies for fine-tuning segmentation models using limited data to enhance performance on unseen subjects and new datasets, achieving significant accuracy improvements.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods relied heavily on large amounts of labeled data, which limited their scalability and generalizability to new subjects.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work demonstrates that effective models can be trained using as few as 15 frames, significantly reducing the reliance on extensive annotated datasets.

key_innovation: The study highlights the capability of deep learning models to adapt effectively to new domains with minimal data input, making it highly relevant for resource-constrained applications.
real_world_impact: This approach enables practical applications in medical imaging and speech processing where data collection is often limited or costly, paving the way for more accessible technologies.
limitations: The study does not explore the performance of the models in a real-time application context.

new_terms.Air-Tissue Boundary (ATB): **Air-Tissue Boundary (ATB)** refers to the interface between air-filled spaces and bodily tissues in MRI scans, crucial for understanding anatomical structures.
new_terms.Pixel-wise Classification Accuracy (PCA): **Pixel-wise Classification Accuracy (PCA)** is a metric used to evaluate the performance of image segmentation models by measuring the percentage of correctly classified pixels.
